title: Transoceanic Fishers: Multiple mobilities in and out of the South China Sea
descriptions:
The proposed project, titled "Transoceanic Fishers: Multiple mobilities in and out of the South China Sea," seeks to examine the complex dynamics of fisher movements and shifting practices in the South China Sea region. The project will involve multiple countries, including China, Vietnam, African countries, and Oceania, and will focus on challenging assumptions about fishers as mere instruments of state agendas. 

Utilizing concepts such as radical marine harvesting techniques, transoceanic networks, and thalassographic analysis, the project will categorize fishers into different groups such as fishers, poachers, traders, and smugglers. The methodology will involve a theoretical and methodological framework, along with fine-grained ethnography of study groups such as Vietnamese, Chinese, African, and Pacific fishers.

The key nodal point of the study will be shore-based activities, with a specific focus on the growing Sino-Vietnamese demand for illicit seafood. The research aims to provide both scientific and policy value, ultimately contributing to a novel understanding of fishers as mobile maritime actors. "TransOcean" represents a significant advancement in the field, offering a unique perspective on the complexities of transoceanic fisher movements.

By challenging the assumption of fishers as instruments of state agendas, the study will utilize radical marine harvesting techniques, transoceanic networks, and fine-grained ethnography to understand the relational and shifting multiple mobilities of Vietnamese, Chinese, African, and Pacific fishers. The research will also explore key nodal points such as shore-based activities and address the growing market demand for illicit seafood between China and Vietnam. By developing a novel theoretical and methodological framework, the project aims to provide scientific and policy value in understanding fishers as mobile maritime actors. The proposed study, TransOcean, seeks to contribute significantly to the field of marine studies and highlight the importance of studying the complexities of fisher movements in the South China Sea.
